Summarize this article for a 10 years old Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) is an [alternative medical practice](/en/Alternative_medicine) drawn from [traditional medicine](/en/Traditional_medicine) in China. It has been described as "fraught with [pseudoscience](/en/Pseudoscience)", with the majority of its treatments having no logical churches](/en/Confucian_church) and sects: Medicine in traditional China encompassed a range of sometimes competing health and healing practices, [folk beliefs](/en/Folk_beliefs), [literati](/en/Scholar-official) theory and [Confucian philosophy](/en/Confucianism), [herbal remedies](/en/Chinese_herbology), exercise, medical specializations, and schools of thought. [[3]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndrews2013b10-17-3) In the early twentieth century, Chinese cultural and political modernizers worked to eliminate traditional practices as backward and unscientific. Traditional practitioners then selected elements of philosophy and practice and organized them into what they called "Chinese medicine" (Zhongyi). [[4]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELei201497-120-4) In the 1950s, the Chinese government sponsored the integration of Chinese and Western medicine, [[5]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor200530-36-5) and in the [Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution](/en/Great_Proletarian_Cultural_Revolution) of the 1960s, promoted Chinese medicine as inexpensive and popular. [[6]](#cite_note-Gushi_2019-6) After the opening of relations between the United States and China after 1972, there was great interest in the West for what is now called traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). [[7]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2005138-141-7) TCM is said to be based on such texts as [Huangdi Neijing](/en/Huangdi_Neijing) (The Inner Canon of the Yellow Emperor), and [Compendium of Materia Medica](/en/Compendium_of_Materia_Medica), a sixteenth-century encyclopedic work, is widely used in the [Sinosphere](/en/East_Asian_cultural_sphere). One of the basic tenets is that the body's [qi](/en/Qi) is circulating through channels called [meridians](/en/Meridian_(Chinese_medicine)) having branches connected to bodily organs and functions. [[8]](#cite_note-Quackwatch-8) There is no evidence that meridians or vital energy exist. Concepts of the body and of disease used in TCM reflect its ancient origins and its emphasis on dynamic processes over material structure, similar to the [humoral theory](/en/Humoral_theory) of [ancient Greece](/en/Ancient_Greek_medicine) and [ancient Rome](/en/Medicine_in_ancient_Rome).
